description:
Human parechovirus 1 (HPeV1) is a small, non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that belongs to the Parechovirus genus within the Picornaviridae family. It is one of the most common human parechoviruses and is known to cause a wide range of clinical manifestations, particularly in infants and young children.

The genome of HPeV1 is approximately 7.5 kilobases in length and contains a single open reading frame that encodes a polyprotein. This polyprotein is subsequently cleaved by viral proteases into the structural and non-structural proteins necessary for viral replication and assembly.

HPeV1 is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route, and it can also be transmitted via respiratory droplets. The virus is known to target and infect the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory system, and central nervous system, leading to a variety of clinical presentations, including gastroenteritis, respiratory illness, and neurological complications, such as meningitis and encephalitis.

Diagnosis of HPeV1 infection typically involves the detection of viral RNA or antigens in clinical samples, such as stool, respiratory secretions, or cerebrospinal fluid, using techniques like reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).

Treatment for HPeV1 infection is primarily supportive, focusing on managing the symptoms and providing appropriate medical care. Preventive measures, such as good hygiene practices and hand washing, can help reduce the transmission of the virus.

Human parechovirus 1 is an important pathogen that continues to be studied to better understand its epidemiology, pathogenesis, and potential clinical implications, particularly in the pediatric population.
